bibl.title: Ernest Hutchinson v. City of Seattle. Petition.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US Circuit Courts, Western District Of Washington, Seattle; Law Register Northern Division, 1899-1906, vol2.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT OF THE NINTH CIRCUIT IN AND FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION
In the Matter of the Petition of Ernest Hutchinson for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable C.H. Hanford, Judge.
The petition of Ernest Hutchinson respectfully represents to your honor.
I.

Your petitioner is a citizen of the United States, and of the State of Michigan, having his home and domicile in the city of Battle Creek in the State of Michigan, where he is engaged in the business of general advertising merchandising and merchandising advertising and in manufacturing for and selling to the trade in the Unites States "Buyer's Stamps", otherwise called "Trading Stamps".
II.

That your petitioner is a memberof the firm of Hutchinson and Hutchinson, doing business under the name and style of "The National Stamp Co.", and which said company has its principal place of business in the said City of Battle Creek in said State of Michigan.
III.
That the purposes and objects of said company are:

To buy, sell, and exchange merchandise; to do a general merchandise and generaladvertising business; to print, issue and circulate advertisements; to make and carry out contracts with corporations and individuals; to advertise their business by special and useful devices; to give merchandise in echange for Buyers' Stamps, commonly known as "Trading Stamps" and which said stamps are to be due bills, certificates or vouchers to be sold by the said company, and to be redeemed by it in merchandise, according to it contracts, rules and regulations.
IV.

That said "Buyers' Stamp" is issued by and as a due bill of said National Stamp Co. and is reduced by said company in exchange for merchandise at the store or place of business of the said company in the City of Seattle or any other city, town or place in the Unites States where said company has an office or is doing business as aforesaid.
V.

That said stamps of said company are sold to the trade at the rate of fifty cents and a hundred and are given by the trade or merchant as a cash discount to each purchaser, one stamp to each ten cents represented in the purchase and whcih said stamps are redeemed by said stamp company in merchandise at its place of bsuiness at room 81, Hinckley Block in said city of Seattle; and that said stamps are used only as a means of advertising the business of petitioners and of the merchants using the same, as a medium of co-operation and exchange for value.
VI.

Petitioner attaches hereto and makes part hereof a stamp book used in the said bisiness of petiutioner marked Exhibit "A", which said exhibit "A" is for the convenience and information of the people doing business with said stamp company and the merchants using said stamps and which said book explains the method of obtaining, using and redeeming said stamps.
VII.

Petitioner attaches hereto and makes part hereof, marked Exhibit "B", a true and correct copy of the said ordinance No. 6036, under which petitioner was apprehended and is now unlawfully deprived of his liberty, property and constitutional rights.
VIII.

Petitioner attaches hereto and makes part hereof, marked Exhibit "C", a true and correct copy of the complaint, filed against petitioner and upon which he is unlawfully held and deprived of his liberty and which said complaint is founded upon said ordiance No. 6036.
Wherefore, your petitioner demurs to said complaint and for cause of demurrer alleges:
1st: That the information and complaint against petitioner charges no offense or crime, because
2nd: The said ordinance No. 6036 under which petitioner is deprives
of his liberty and upon which said complaint is founded is unconsti- tutional and void in this, to-wit:
a. That said ordinance is against public policy.
b. That said ordinance is in restraint of trade and commerce between the people of this State.
c. That said ordinance is in restraint of Inter-State trade and commerce
d. That said ordinance is special legislation and wrongfully, unlawfully and unreasonably discriminates against the lawful business affairs of petitioner.
e. That said ordinance unlawfully, wrongfully and unconstitutionally deprives petitioner of his liberty and right to fully contract and carry on lawful business, trade and commerce.

f. That said ordinance unlawfully, wrongfully and unconstitutionally prohibits and restrains petitioner from engaging in lawful business and takes away and destroys property without due process of law.
g. That said ordinance imposes an unreasonable and unjust burden upon petitioner and upon trade and commerce, and is in violation of his constitutional rights.

h. That said ordinance is in violation of the Constitution of the State of Washington and of the United States; and that the City Council of the City of Seattle has no power or authority to enact said ordinance and the legislation of the State of Washington has not given and cannot give such power or authority to said city council or any city council.
i. That said ordinance impairs and interferes with petitioner's right to engage in lawful business.
j. That said ordinance unlawfully interferes with petitioner's right to engage in lawful business.
k. That said ordinance is oppressive, discriminating, prohibitory and unreasonable.
IX.
That your petitioner is unlawfully restrained of his liberty by the Chief of Police, Seattle, at the City Hall in the said City of Seattle.
X.

That said Chief of Police, Seattle, pretends to and does hold petitioner a prisoner and unlawfully deprives and restraines petitioner of his liberty and constitutional rights under and by virtue of a pretended complaint and judgment based upon said unconstitutional and void ordinance, No. 6036.

Your petitioner therefor prays that a Writ of Habeas Corpus may issue, directed to the said Chief of Police, Seattle, commanding him that he have the body of the said Ernst Hutchinson by him imprisoned and detained, together with the time and cause of said imprisonment and detetion, before Hon. C.H. Hanford, Judge of aforesaid Court, at the United States Court, cor. 4th Ave. and Marian St., in the City of Seattle, County of King, State of Washington, at on the day of 1904, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered or ordered concerning the said Ernst Hutchinson, in pursuance of the statute in such case made and provided.
Dates this 12th day of April A.D. 1904
Carrol A. Carroll
Attorneys for Petitioner
